metadata.title: The Brook
metadata.subject: English
metadata.description: A beautiful poem by Alfred Lord Tennyson where a brook (small stream) speaks in first person, describing its long journey from the mountains to the brimming river. The poem uses rich sound words and the famous refrain about the eternity of nature vs. the temporary nature of human life. Grammar focus: Prepositions.

preAssessment.question: In the poem, who is speaking?
What is the famous refrain (repeated lines) in the poem?
options: A) 'I go on and on forever'
B) 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever'
C) 'The brook flows and flows forever'
D) 'Nature is eternal, man is not'

preAssessment.question: Which of these is a sound word used in the poem?
What is a preposition?
options: A) A word that describes a noun
B) A word that shows the relationship between a noun and another word in a sentence
C) A word that replaces a noun
D) A word that joins two sentences

concepts.title: Alfred Lord Tennyson and Personification
concepts.content: Alfred Lord Tennyson (1809‚Äì1892) was one of England's greatest poets. He was the Poet Laureate of Great Britain during the reign of Queen Victoria. 'The Brook' is one of his most famous poems. The most interesting feature of the poem is that it is written from the brook's point of view ‚Äî the brook speaks in first person ('I chatter over stony ways', 'I slip, I slide'). This literary technique is called Personification ‚Äî giving human qualities, speech, or feelings to something that is not human. Here, the brook 'talks' and 'feels' and 'moves' as if it were a living person. Personification makes nature feel alive and relatable. The brook becomes a character with its own voice and personality.
examples: Personification: 'The brook sings' ‚Äî brooks do not really sing, but we give them this human quality.
In Indian poetry and literature, rivers like the Ganga and Yamuna are also personified ‚Äî they are called 'Mother Ganga' and 'Yamuna Maiya'.
Tennyson was so famous that Queen Victoria personally appointed him as Poet Laureate ‚Äî the official poet of England.
keyPoints: Poet: Alfred Lord Tennyson (1809‚Äì1892) ‚Äî Poet Laureate of England under Queen Victoria
The brook speaks in first person ‚Äî uses 'I' throughout the poem
Personification = giving human qualities to non-human things
The brook describes its own journey from mountains to river
'The Brook' is one of Tennyson's most famous and beloved poems
concepts.funFact: Alfred Lord Tennyson became Poet Laureate in 1850 and held the position for 42 years ‚Äî the longest anyone has ever held that honour! He wrote 'The Charge of the Light Brigade' and 'In Memoriam' among his famous works.
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 17, Pages 68-70, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

concepts.title: The Brook's Journey
concepts.content: The poem traces the brook's long, eventful journey. It begins its journey from the 'haunts of coot and hern' (the sheltered places where waterfowl like coots and herons live) in the hills. It flows down thirty hills, past twenty thorpes (small villages), and under half a hundred (fifty) bridges. It passes by fields and ferns, and flows through valleys and plains. Eventually, it joins the 'brimming river' ‚Äî a large, full river. Along the way, it notices everything: fish swimming in it, flowers on its banks, pebbles on its bed, boats passing over it. The brook's journey is like a long, exciting adventure ‚Äî starting small in the mountains and growing bigger as it flows toward the great river.
examples: The brook's journey is like how rivers start as small streams in the Western Ghats of Maharashtra and then grow into rivers like the Godavari and Krishna.
'Haunts of coot and hern' ‚Äî in Maharashtra, you can see herons near streams and rivulets in rural areas.
'Half a hundred bridges' = fifty bridges ‚Äî the brook is so long that it passes under fifty bridges in its journey!
keyPoints: Brook starts from haunts of coot and hern (waterfowl in the hills)
Flows down thirty hills and past twenty thorpes (small villages)
Passes under half a hundred (fifty) bridges
Flows through fields and ferns
Finally joins the 'brimming river' ‚Äî a large, full-flowing river
concepts.funFact: A 'thorpe' is an old English word for a small village or hamlet. You can still find many English villages with 'thorpe' in their names ‚Äî like Scunthorpe and Cleethorpes. English place names often preserve ancient words like this!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 17, Pages 68-70, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

concepts.title: Sound Words and Imagery
concepts.content: One of the most beautiful things about 'The Brook' is its rich use of sound words (also called onomatopoeia ‚Äî words that sound like what they describe). The brook uses many action and sound words to describe how it moves and sounds: 'chatter' (to talk rapidly ‚Äî the brook makes chattering sounds over stones), 'bubble' (to make bubbling sounds), 'babble' (to make continuous, murmuring sounds), 'murmur' (to make a soft, gentle sound), 'slip' and 'slide' (to move smoothly), 'gloom' (to move through dark, shaded areas), 'glance' (to catch the light briefly). When you read these words aloud, you can almost hear the brook moving! This is the magic of Tennyson's poetry ‚Äî the words themselves sound like water flowing.
examples: 'I chatter over stony ways' ‚Äî say it aloud and you can almost hear the bubbling sound of water running over stones.
'I babble on the pebbles' ‚Äî the word 'babble' itself sounds like water bubbling gently.
Like the brook, the Koyna River in Maharashtra makes chattering sounds as it flows over rocky beds in the Sahyadri hills.
keyPoints: Sound words (onomatopoeia): chatter, bubble, babble, murmur
Movement words: slip, slide, gloom, glance
These words make you almost hear and see the brook moving
When read aloud, the poem sounds like flowing water
Tennyson was a master of musical language ‚Äî his words create music
concepts.funFact: Scientists have studied the psychological effect of water sounds and found that the sound of a babbling brook reduces stress and anxiety! Tennyson chose exactly the right words because they actually sound like real water.
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 17, Pages 68-70, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

concepts.title: The Refrain and Its Meaning
concepts.content: A refrain is a line or group of lines that is repeated at regular intervals in a poem. In 'The Brook', the famous refrain is: 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever.' This refrain appears multiple times throughout the poem. Its meaning is profound: human beings (men) are temporary ‚Äî they are born, they live, and they die. But the brook (and nature) is eternal ‚Äî it flows on forever, generation after generation. The brook has seen countless humans live and die beside it, but the brook itself never stops. This is a contrast between the temporary nature of human life and the permanence of nature. It is a gentle, philosophical reminder about how powerful and eternal nature is compared to our short human lives.
examples: The Ganga River in India has been flowing for millions of years ‚Äî countless generations of Indians have been born and died on its banks, but the Ganga flows on forever.
The refrain is like a chorus in a Hindi film song ‚Äî it repeats to emphasize the most important message.
Philosophers like Buddha and the Bhagavad Gita also say that the soul is eternal while the body is temporary ‚Äî the same idea as the brook's refrain.
keyPoints: Refrain = lines repeated at regular intervals in a poem
The refrain: 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever'
Meaning: Humans are temporary, but nature (the brook) is eternal
The brook contrasts its own permanence with human mortality
This refrain makes the poem both musical and deeply meaningful
concepts.funFact: The phrase 'men may come and men may go' from this poem has become so famous that people use it in everyday English to mean that nothing depends on any one person ‚Äî life and work go on regardless!
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 17, Pages 68-70, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

concepts.title: Grammar ‚Äî Prepositions
concepts.content: A preposition is a word that shows the relationship between a noun (or pronoun) and another word in the sentence. Prepositions usually tell us about position, direction, time, or manner. The poem 'The Brook' is full of prepositions that show how the brook moves: 'by' (the brook flows BY the farm ‚Äî showing position), 'through' (it flows THROUGH the meadows ‚Äî showing passage), 'along' (it flows ALONG the valley ‚Äî showing direction), 'over' (it flows OVER the stones ‚Äî showing above), 'under' (it flows UNDER the bridges ‚Äî showing beneath). Common prepositions: in, on, at, by, over, under, through, along, beside, between, among, into, from, to, with, during, before, after.
examples: 'The book is ON the table' ‚Äî ON shows the position of the book.
'The brook flows THROUGH the valley' ‚Äî THROUGH shows the path of movement.
'She sat BESIDE the river' ‚Äî BESIDE shows the position next to the river.
keyPoints: Preposition = word that shows relationship between a noun and another word
Shows: position (on, under, over), direction (to, from, through), time (before, after, during)
Prepositions from the poem: by, through, along, over, under
Common prepositions: in, on, at, by, over, under, through, beside, between
A preposition is always followed by a noun or pronoun (called the object of the preposition)
concepts.funFact: The word 'preposition' comes from Latin 'prae' (before) + 'ponere' (to place) ‚Äî because prepositions are placed BEFORE the noun they relate to. English has over 150 prepositions! In Marathi, these same relationships are shown by 'vibhakti' (case endings) rather than separate words.
concepts.textbookRef: Chapter 17, Pages 68-70, Maharashtra Board 7th Grade English

test.question: Who wrote the poem 'The Brook'?
test.explanation: Alfred Lord Tennyson (1809‚Äì1892) wrote 'The Brook'. He was the Poet Laureate of England and one of the greatest Victorian poets.

test.question: Who speaks in the poem 'The Brook'?
options: A) A fisherman telling about the brook
B) The poet describing the brook
C) The brook itself, in first person
D) A village elder near the brook
test.explanation: In 'The Brook', the brook itself speaks in first person ‚Äî it says 'I chatter', 'I slip', 'I slide'. This technique of giving human qualities to nature is called personification.

test.question: What does the brook finally join at the end of its journey?
test.explanation: After its long journey ‚Äî down thirty hills, past twenty thorpes, under fifty bridges ‚Äî the brook finally joins the 'brimming river', a large, full-flowing river.

test.question: What is the famous refrain of the poem?
options: A) 'The brook flows forever over stones'
B) 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever'
C) 'Nature is eternal, life is short'
D) 'I slip and I slide and I gloom and I glance'
test.explanation: The famous refrain is 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever.' It means humans are temporary but the brook (nature) is eternal.

test.question: Which sound word means 'to make a continuous murmuring sound like water'?
test.explanation: 'Babble' means to make continuous, murmuring sounds like water flowing over pebbles. It is one of the sound words that makes the poem musical.

test.question: In 'The brook flows through the valley', what is the preposition?
test.explanation: 'Through' is the preposition ‚Äî it shows the relationship between the brook's movement and the valley (it flows through/inside the valley).

test.question: How many bridges does the brook pass under in the poem?
test.explanation: The brook passes under 'half a hundred bridges', which means fifty bridges. It also flows down thirty hills and past twenty thorpes (small villages).

test.question: What technique is used in the poem when the brook speaks like a human being?
test.explanation: Personification is the technique used ‚Äî giving human qualities, speech, or feelings to something that is not human. The brook speaks using 'I', as if it were a person.

test.question: What is the message of the refrain 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever'?
options: A) Men are stronger than nature
B) Nature is eternal but human life is temporary
C) Men should live near brooks
D) The brook is sad that men leave it
test.explanation: The refrain means that while humans are born and die (temporary), the brook ‚Äî representing nature ‚Äî flows on forever (eternal). It contrasts the permanence of nature with the brevity of human life.

keyConcepts: Alfred Lord Tennyson ‚Äî Victorian Poet Laureate of England
Personification ‚Äî brook speaks in first person (I chatter, I slide)
Brook's journey: haunts of coot and hern ‚Üí 30 hills ‚Üí 20 thorpes ‚Üí 50 bridges ‚Üí brimming river
Sound words: chatter, bubble, babble, murmur, slip, slide, gloom, glance
Refrain: 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever'
Theme: nature is eternal; human life is temporary
Prepositions: by, through, along, over, under
commonMisconceptions: Students may think 'personification' means the brook is actually alive ‚Äî it is a literary device where we IMAGINE the brook as a person.
Students may confuse refrain with rhyme ‚Äî a refrain is a REPEATED group of lines, while rhyme refers to matching end sounds.
Students may think 'thorpe' means a city ‚Äî it actually means a small village or hamlet (old English word).
Preposition confusion: 'at', 'in', and 'on' are all prepositions of place but used differently ‚Äî on a table, in a box, at the school.
realWorldExamples: Rivers in Maharashtra like the Godavari, Krishna, and Koyna start as small brooks in the Sahyadri hills ‚Äî exactly like the brook in the poem.
The concept of rivers being eternal ('Ganga flows forever') is deeply embedded in Indian culture ‚Äî the same idea as the poem's refrain.
Prepositions are used constantly in everyday Marathi speech too ‚Äî 'te over pul' (it flows over the bridge) uses the same prepositional relationship.
Bird watching near brooks and streams is a popular activity in Maharashtra ‚Äî students can spot herons (hern) and coots near local water bodies, just like in the poem.

interactiveElement.title: Vocabulary Flashcards!
interactiveElement.description: Flip each card to reveal the meaning of the word.

cards.back: A small, natural stream of water

cards.front: What poetic device is used when the brook 'speaks'?
cards.back: Personification - giving human qualities to non-human things

cards.front: What does 'I chatter over stony ways' mean?
cards.back: The brook makes noise as it flows over rocks
Alfred Lord Tennyson, a famous English poet

cards.front: What is the mood of the poem 'The Brook'?
cards.back: Joyful, lively, and celebratory of nature

textbookExercise.instructions: Memorize these exam-style answers to maximize scoring in textbook-focused assessments.

qaCards.question: Who wrote the poem 'The Brook'?
qaCards.answer: Alfred Lord Tennyson (1809‚Äì1892) wrote 'The Brook'. He was the Poet Laureate of England and one of the greatest Victorian poets.

qaCards.question: Who speaks in the poem 'The Brook'?
qaCards.answer: In 'The Brook', the brook itself speaks in first person ‚Äî it says 'I chatter', 'I slip', 'I slide'. This technique of giving human qualities to nature is called personification.

qaCards.question: What does the brook finally join at the end of its journey?
qaCards.answer: After its long journey ‚Äî down thirty hills, past twenty thorpes, under fifty bridges ‚Äî the brook finally joins the 'brimming river', a large, full-flowing river.

qaCards.question: What is the famous refrain of the poem?
qaCards.answer: The famous refrain is 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever.' It means humans are temporary but the brook (nature) is eternal.

qaCards.question: Which sound word means 'to make a continuous murmuring sound like water'?
qaCards.answer: 'Babble' means to make continuous, murmuring sounds like water flowing over pebbles. It is one of the sound words that makes the poem musical.

qaCards.question: In 'The brook flows through the valley', what is the preposition?
qaCards.answer: 'Through' is the preposition ‚Äî it shows the relationship between the brook's movement and the valley (it flows through/inside the valley).

qaCards.question: How many bridges does the brook pass under in the poem?
qaCards.answer: The brook passes under 'half a hundred bridges', which means fifty bridges. It also flows down thirty hills and past twenty thorpes (small villages).

qaCards.question: What technique is used in the poem when the brook speaks like a human being?
qaCards.answer: Personification is the technique used ‚Äî giving human qualities, speech, or feelings to something that is not human. The brook speaks using 'I', as if it were a person.

qaCards.question: What is the message of the refrain 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever'?
qaCards.answer: The refrain means that while humans are born and die (temporary), the brook ‚Äî representing nature ‚Äî flows on forever (eternal). It contrasts the permanence of nature with the brevity of human life.

longAnswers.question: Describe the journey of the brook as mentioned in the poem.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The brook begins its journey from the haunts of coot and hern, making a sudden sally down the hills. It hurries past thirty hills, slips between ridges, and flows by twenty thorpes, a little town, and half a hundred bridges. Finally, it flows by Philip's farm to join the brimming river. Throughout its journey, it chatters over stony ways and babbles on the pebbles, displaying a lively and unceasing energy.
keyPoints: Starts from the haunts of coot and hern and rushes down.
Flows past thirty hills, twenty thorpes, a little town, and fifty bridges.
Finally passes Philip's farm to join the brimming river.
Characterized by lively movements and continuous energetic sounds.

longAnswers.question: Explain the central theme of the poem 'The Brook'.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The central theme of the poem is the contrast between the eternal nature of the brook and the transient nature of human life. This is highlighted by the refrain, 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever.' While human beings have a short lifespan and inevitably pass away, the brook continues its journey endlessly. The poem uses the brook's continuous flow to symbolize the permanence of nature as opposed to human mortality.
keyPoints: Contrasts the eternal nature of the brook with transient human life.
The refrain emphasizes that humans come and go, but the brook is forever.
Human beings have a limited lifespan and eventually pass away.
The brook symbolizes the unending and permanent force of nature.

longAnswers.question: How does the poet use sound words to bring the brook to life?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Alfred Lord Tennyson uses vivid sound words, or onomatopoeia, to describe the brook's movements and make the poem musical. Words like 'chatter', 'babble', 'bubble', and 'murmur' mimic the actual sounds of flowing water over pebbles and stones. This rich imagery helps the reader vividly hear and visualize the water as it slips, slides, and dances along its path. These auditory details bring the brook to life, giving it a lively and energetic personality.
keyPoints: Uses onomatopoeia to mimic the actual sounds of flowing water.
Words like 'chatter', 'babble', 'bubble', and 'murmur' describe its movement.
Auditory details help readers vividly hear and visualize the water.
These sound words give the brook a lively, energetic personality.

longAnswers.question: Discuss the use of personification in the poem 'The Brook'.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: In the poem, the poet uses personification by giving the brook a human voice and personality. The brook narrates its own journey in the first person, using the pronoun 'I' to describe its actions like chattering, loitering, and murmuring. By giving human-like qualities to a natural stream, Tennyson makes the brook an active, living character rather than a lifeless object. This technique allows readers to connect deeply with the brook's adventurous journey to the river.
keyPoints: The brook is personified by being given a human voice and personality.
It narrates its own journey in the first person using 'I'.
It performs human-like actions such as chattering, murmuring, and loitering.
This technique makes the brook feel like a living, breathing character.

longAnswers.question: What does the brook carry with it on its way to the brimming river?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: As the brook flows toward the brimming river, it carries several elements of nature along with it. It takes along blossoms sailing on its surface, and lively trout and grayling fish swimming in its waters. The brook also carries foamy flakes and draws along various weeds as it winds about. These details create a vibrant picture of a thriving, dynamic ecosystem moving alongside the water.
keyPoints: The brook carries floating blossoms on its surface.
It supports aquatic life like lusty trout and grayling fish.
Foamy flakes and water weeds are drawn along in its current.
These elements illustrate a vibrant and dynamic natural ecosystem.
